# Draft:Cao Gui Talking War

In the spring of the tenth year, the army of the State of Qi attacked our state (Lu). The Duke (Duke Zhuang of Lu) was about to go to battle. Cao Gui requested an audience.
A fellow villager said:
“Those who eat meat (i.e., the nobles and ministers) are already deliberating the matter—why should you get involved?”
Cao Gui replied:
“Those who eat meat are narrow-minded and short-sighted. They cannot plan far ahead.”
He then went in to see the Duke.
On Justification for War
Cao Gui asked:
“By what means will you engage in battle?”
The Duke replied:
“I ensure the people have food and clothing, and I do not monopolize them. I share with the people.”
Cao Gui said:
“Such small kindness has not yet reached everyone—so the people will not follow you.”
The Duke added:
“I offer sacrificial animals and jade to the spirits—I dare not be excessive, and always keep my word.”
Cao Gui replied:
“Such small faith is not yet trustworthy to the gods—so they will not bless you.”
The Duke said:
“When judging legal disputes, whether great or small, though I cannot always see clearly, I always strive for fairness.”
Cao Gui responded:
“That is a matter of justice and loyalty. On this basis, we can fight. If we must fight, let me join you.”
In Battle
The Duke allowed him to ride in the chariot. They fought at Changshao.
The Duke was about to order the drumbeat to attack.
Cao Gui said:
“Not yet.”
The Qi army beat their drums three times.
Cao Gui then said:
“Now is the time!”
The Lu army attacked, and the Qi army was defeated.
The Duke wanted to give chase.
Cao Gui said:
“Not yet.”
He got down to observe the enemy's tracks, then climbed up the front of the chariot to observe their banners and said:
“Now it is appropriate.”
Then they pursued and routed the Qi army.
On Military Strategy
After the victory, the Duke asked about the reason behind the timing.
Cao Gui replied:
“Warfare depends on morale.
At the first drumbeat, soldiers are full of spirit.
At the second, their spirit wanes.
At the third, it is exhausted.
Their energy was spent while ours was still full—this is why we won.
And large states are unpredictable—there may be an ambush.
When I saw their tracks were disordered and their banners were drooping, I knew they were truly in retreat. That’s why I pursued them.”
